instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light with 65w charger
threads.message:
Hi
Today I got a Macbook back as it wont charge and no green light with costumers two 65w original chargers, tested with the 85w charger I use and got green light and charging. Tested costumer charger on another Macbook and works just fine. It boots normal and no other fault at all.

Whats wrong with this, never seen this before.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light with 65w charger
threads.message:
I bet for input leakage, which blocks 65W charger.
Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> first.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no green light with 65w charger
threads.message:
Thank you, 
You was correct, changed <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and now I get green light and charging with 65w charger
